THIS IS WHY  $BTC IS NOT PUMPING HARD AFTER MSCI NEWS üö® 

MSCI has announced not to remove Bitcoin and crypto treasury companies from its indexes.

But they have added a new rule.

When treasury companies issue new shares, MSCI will not add those extra shares to its indexes.

Earlier, when Strategy and other treasury companies used to issue new shares, big index funds had to buy some of those new shares.

Now, those funds won't need to buy the new shares anymore.

This means the automatic buying demand has now gone, and it'll be less attractive to issue new shares.

The result of this will be less money raised through share dilution, and this is why markets are not going bonkers.

Golden Cross vs. Death Cross: Context is King üìä‚öñÔ∏è In the 2026 market, many traders still mistake lagging indicators for crystal balls. While the Golden Cross and Death Cross are powerful tools for framing sentiment, they are not predictive signals.  The Strategic Breakdown:  What they are: These signals are based on moving averages, meaning they reflect where the price was, not where it is going.  Confirmation Power: Their real value lies in confirming a structural trend that has already begun, such as the current institutional push in $BTC .  The Context Trap: Using them in isolation often leads to "fake-outs." They work best when aligned with volume and macro fundamentals.  The Bottom Line: Don't trade the cross; trade the trend that the cross is confirming. 15B Forced Selling Taken Off Table Can
MSCI's decision push BTC to $100k?


A few months ago, MSCI (the giant behind global stock indexes) proposed kicking out companies like MicroStrategy that hold more than 50% of their assets in Bitcoin and crypto. If it had gone through, passive funds tracking those indexes would have been forced to dump an estimated $10-15 billion worth of shares, putting massive selling pressure on MSTR stock and even dragging Bitcoin lower. The crypto community and Michael Saylor fought back hard, and the uncertainty weighed on the market for weeks.
Yesterday, the good news finally dropped: MSCI backed off and confirmed they won't exclude these treasury companies, at least for the February 2026 review. MSTR jumped about 6%, Bitcoin turned positive and climbed toward $93-94K, and the biggest overhang is now gone. There's still talk of a broader consultation down the road, but for now it's a clear win that many believe could help push ‡∏ø

$100K and beyond.

MSCI‚Äôs decision doesn‚Äôt create new demand by itself, but it protects existing capital from being forced out. And in markets like BTC, removing supply pressure can be just as powerful as adding buyers.  If demand stays steady (or increases with ETFs, institutions, and macro tailwinds), $BTC  doesn‚Äôt need extreme inflows to move higher. With less resistance on the sell side, 100k$ becomes a realistic scenario, not a stretch target.  So the short answer: üëâ MSCI didn‚Äôt push BTC to 100k$. üëâ But it removed a major obstacle that was standing in the way.  The next move now depends on follow through, not fear.
